<ce:section-title id="sect0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0100" view="all">Reaction of 2-(2′-pyridyl)benzoxazole (2-PBO), 2-(4′-pyridyl)benzoxazole (4-PBO) and 2,2-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1,3-benzoxazole (BBO) ligands with CuX (X = I, Br, SCN) afforded a binuclear copper(I) complex [Cu(2-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-I)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and three copper(I) coordination polymers [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-PBO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SCN)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Cu(BBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Br)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). The structural analysis revealed that the all copper(I) ions are four-coordinated and the geometric structure around the central copper(I) atom possessing slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Halogen or pseudohalide ions can not only act as counter anions, but also as ligands participation in coordination when the cuprous ion coordination sites are not saturated. Due to the different coordination modes of the benzoxazole ligands, in order to satisfy the tetra-coordination of cuprous ions, halogen or pseudohalide ions adopt μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and/or μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging modes to synergistically complete coordination. Photoluminescence investigation show that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have two emission peaks, the high energy band peak is attributed to MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT, the low energy band peak is caused by the <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>CC emission. This may be due to the presence of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-X (X = I, Br, S) in these complexes. However complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> only had one emission peak, which may be attributed to MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Reaction of 2-(2'-pyridyl)benzoxazole (2-PBO), 2-(4'-pyridyl)benzoxazole (4-PBO) and 2,2-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1,3-benzoxazole (BBO) ligands with CuX (X=I, Br, SCN) afforded a binuclear copper(I) complex [Cu(2-PBO)(μ2-I)]2 (1) and three copper(I) coordination polymers [Cu4(4-PBO)4(μ3-I)4]n (2), {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-SCN)]2}n (3) and {[Cu(BBO)(μ2-Br)]2}n (4). The structural analysis revealed that the all copper(I) ions are four-coordinated and the geometric structure around the central copper(I) atom possessing slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in complexes 1-4. Halogen or pseudohalide ions can not only act as counter anions, but also as ligands participation in coordination when the cuprous ion coordination sites are not saturated. Due to the different coordination modes of the benzoxazole ligands, in order to satisfy the tetra-coordination of cuprous ions, halogen or pseudohalide ions adopt μ2 and/or μ3-bridging modes to synergistically complete coordination. Photoluminescence investigation show that complexes 1, 3 and 4 have two emission peaks, the high energy band peak is attributed to MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT, the low energy band peak is caused by the 3CC emission. This may be due to the presence of μ2-X (X=I, Br, S) in these complexes. However complex 2 only had one emission peak, which may be attributed to MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT.

Graphical abstract

Through the use of different types of benzoxazole ligands and the coordination synergistic effect of halogen or pseudohalogen ions, the regulation of the structure of the cuprous complexes 1-4 was achieved. Fluorescence analysis illustrated that there are two emission peaks for complexes 1, 3 and 4 {high energy band: MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT; low energy band: 3CC emission}. However, there is only one emission peaks for complex 2 {MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT}.  fx1

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0020">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Copper(I)-halide complexes are particularly appealing because of their intrinsic architectural beauty and aesthetically pleasing structures, as well as potential applications such as photoluminescence, electric conductivity, adsorption, and heterogeneous catalysis . Cuprous halides or pseudo halides have been explored as metal centers and building units to prepare luminescent complexes and construct coordination networks, where cuprous halides can be used as single metal centers or polynuclear aggregates, such as dimers, tetramers, oligomers and chains, depending on the reaction conditions and ligands . The combination of the electron rich copper(I) center, conjugated organic ligand and high degree of inherent covalence in soft acid-soft base bonding can produce low energy electronic interactions . The ligands and halogen/pseudohalogen play an essential role in stabilizing the copper(I) state and altering the physical and chemical properties of the prepared complexes. Thus careful choices of ligands and halogen/pseudohalogen are of significant importance which will tune the properties and structure of the resulting compound .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Copper(I)-halide complexes are particularly appealing because of their intrinsic architectural beauty and aesthetically pleasing structures, as well as potential applications such as photoluminescence, electric conductivity, adsorption, and heterogeneous catalysis . Cuprous halides or pseudo halides have been explored as metal centers and building units to prepare luminescent complexes and construct coordination networks, where cuprous halides can be used as single metal centers or polynuclear aggregates, such as dimers, tetramers, oligomers and chains, depending on the reaction conditions and ligands . The combination of the electron rich copper(I) center, conjugated organic ligand and high degree of inherent covalence in soft acid-soft base bonding can produce low energy electronic interactions . The ligands and halogen/pseudohalogen play an essential role in stabilizing the copper(I) state and altering the physical and chemical properties of the prepared complexes. Thus careful choices of ligands and halogen/pseudohalogen are of significant importance which will tune the properties and structure of the resulting compound .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">More recently considerable interest has been paid on <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic system, especially benzoxazole and its derivatives which are reported to exhibit remarkable features like ease of preparation, electrochemical behavior and light absorption in the visible region, characteristic structural flexibility, supramolecular architecture, long-lived electronically excited states and intense luminescence . Because of having high thermal stability, good catalytic performance and superior optical properties, metal complexes with benzoxazole ligands are important. An important feature of these compounds is the structural modifications which causes a large p-delocalization over the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligand than that of the regular complexes . The steric crowding and π-acidic character imparted by these ligands are most important prerequisites for stabilizing the copper(I) complexes and their redox, photophysical and catalytic behavior.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: More recently considerable interest has been paid on N-heterocyclic system, especially benzoxazole and its derivatives which are reported to exhibit remarkable features like ease of preparation, electrochemical behavior and light absorption in the visible region, characteristic structural flexibility, supramolecular architecture, long-lived electronically excited states and intense luminescence . Because of having high thermal stability, good catalytic performance and superior optical properties, metal complexes with benzoxazole ligands are important. An important feature of these compounds is the structural modifications which causes a large p-delocalization over the N-heterocyclic ligand than that of the regular complexes . The steric crowding and π-acidic character imparted by these ligands are most important prerequisites for stabilizing the copper(I) complexes and their redox, photophysical and catalytic behavior.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">In this work, four different structural cuprous complexes {[Cu(2-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-I)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-PBO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>, {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SCN)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> and {[Cu(BBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Br)]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> were synthesized by using three different types of benzoxazole ligands (monodentate, chelating and bridging) to control the bridging of halogen/pseudohalogen ions. The fluorescence properties of the four complexes were studied. The effects of structure on performance have been discussed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this work, four different structural cuprous complexes {[Cu(2-PBO)(μ2-I)]2, [Cu4(4-PBO)4(μ3-I)4]n, {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-SCN)]2}n and {[Cu(BBO)(μ2-Br)]2}n were synthesized by using three different types of benzoxazole ligands (monodentate, chelating and bridging) to control the bridging of halogen/pseudohalogen ions. The fluorescence properties of the four complexes were studied. The effects of structure on performance have been discussed.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reactions were carried out under a nitrogen atmosphere, using anhydrous solvents or solvents treated with an appropriate drying reagent. Commercially available reagents were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. Elemental analyses were determined using a Carlo Erba 1106 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded from 4000 to 400cm-1 with a Nicolet FT-VERTEX 70 spectrometer using KBr pellets. 1H NMR spectra were obtained with a Mercury plus 400MHz NMR spectrometer with TMS as internal standard and DMSO-d 6 as solvent. UV-Vis absorption was recorded on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using a Siemens D5005 diffractometer with Cu-Kα (λ=1.5418Å) radiation. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra, emission lifetimes, and absolute emission quantum yields were recorded on an Edinburgh FLS980 spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Average lifetime which is calculated by the equation τave =∑Aiτi/∑Ai with Ai as the pre-exponential factor for the lifetime. Absolute photoluminescence quantum yield with relative error =±10%.

Preparation of the cuprous complexes 1-4

Synthesis of [Cu(2-PBO)(μ2-I)]2 (1)

To a stirred solution of ligand 2-PBO (0.0196g, 0.10mmol) in hot MeOH (10mL) was added CuI (0.0190g, 0.10mmol) in CH3CN (5mL). The block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by evaporation the mixed solution after two weeks at room temperature. 89% yield. Anal. Calcd for C24H16Cu2I2N4O2:C, 37.28; H, 2.09; N, 7.25%. Found:C, 38.29; H, 2.27; N, 8.52%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3055 (w), 1541 (w), 1469 (m), 1429 (m), 1356 (s), 1257 (w), 1126 (m), 810 (m), 744 (s), 696 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO):δ (ppm)=7.46-7.88(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.03-8.42(m, 3H, H-Py), 8.88-8.92(m, 1H, H-Py).

A large amount of dark red and block-shaped crystals of were found. Yield: 92%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3047 (w), 2926 (w), 1539 (w), 1473 (m), 1419 (s), 1346 (m), 1271 (m), 1111 (w), 1058 (w), 842 (m), 810 (m), 740 (s), 698 (m), 511 (w). <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR (400 MHz, d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-DMSO): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> (ppm) = 7.51–7.92(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.12–8.34(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.77–8.96(m, 2H, H-C-N, H-Py).</ce:para>

Synthesis of [Cu4(4-PBO)4(μ3-I)4]n (2)

A mixture of 4-PBO (0.1mmol), CuI (0.2mmol), acetonitrile (8.0mL) wassealed in a stainless steel reactor with a 15mL Teflon liner and heated at 140°C for 3 days, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. A large amount of dark red and block-shaped crystals of were found. Yield: 92%. Calcd for C12H8CuIN2O: C, 37.28; H, 2.09; N, 7.25%. Found: C, 37.19; H, 2.02; N, 7.18%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3047 (w), 2926 (w), 1539 (w), 1473 (m), 1419 (s), 1346 (m), 1271 (m), 1111 (w), 1058 (w), 842 (m), 810 (m), 740 (s), 698 (m), 511 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO): δ (ppm)=7.51-7.92(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.12-8.34(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.77-8.96(m, 2H, H-C-N, H-Py).

A clear solution of CuSCN (0.0243 g, 0.2 mmol) and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN (0.0304 g, 0.4 mmol) in 4 mL of acetonitrile was then very carefully layered on the top of the buffer solution. After 1 week, red block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 78%. Elemental analysis for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OS: C, 49.13; H, 2.54; N, 5.03%. Found: C, 49.06; H, 2.46; N, 4.95%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3109 (w), 2364 (w), 2048 (m), 1620 (s), 1546 (m), 1421 (m), 1350 (w), 1220 (w), 1060 (w), 814 (m), 752 (s), 692 (w). <ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>H NMR (400 MHz, d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-DMSO): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> (ppm) = 7.48–7.88(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.03–8.22(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.89–8.97(m, 2H, H-Py).</ce:para>

Synthesis of {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-SCN)]2}n (3)

A solution of 2-PBO (0.0588g, 0.3mmol) in 4mL of dichloromethane was very carefully placed on the bottom of the tube. 1mL of acetonitrile as the buffer was slowly layered onto the ligand solution. A clear solution of CuSCN (0.0243g, 0.2mmol) and NH4SCN (0.0304g, 0.4mmol) in 4mL of acetonitrile was then very carefully layered on the top of the buffer solution. After 1 week, red block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 78%. Elemental analysis for C13H8CuN3OS: C, 49.13; H, 2.54; N, 5.03%. Found: C, 49.06; H, 2.46; N, 4.95%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3109 (w), 2364 (w), 2048 (m), 1620 (s), 1546 (m), 1421 (m), 1350 (w), 1220 (w), 1060 (w), 814 (m), 752 (s), 692 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO): δ (ppm)=7.48-7.88(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.03-8.22(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.89-8.97(m, 2H, H-Py).

Synthesis of {[Cu(BBO)(μ2-Br)]2}n (4)

The synthesis of complex 4 is similar to 2 except for using BBO (0.1mmol) and CuBr (0.2mmol). Calcd for C18H16BrCuN2O2: C, 49.61; H, 3.70; N, 6.43%. Found: C, 49.52; H, 3.66; N, 6.39%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3053 (w), 2943 (w), 1604 (w), 1560 (s), 1454 (m), 1244 (m), 1166 (w), 779 (w), 744 (s). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO):δ (ppm)=2.11-2.19(m, 4H, H-CH2), 3.12-3.33(m, 4H, H-CH2), 7.45-7.92(m, 8H, -H-Ar).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0060">Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Suitable single crystals of complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> were mounted on a glass fiber, and the intensity data were collected on a Bruker APEXII area detector with graphite-monochromated MoKa radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed using the SMART and SAINT programs . The absorption corrections are carried out by the empirical method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least squares against F<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> of data using SHELXTL software . All H atoms were found in different electron maps and were subsequently refined in a riding-model approximation with C-H distances ranging from 0.95 to 0.99 Å . Information concerning the crystallographic data collection and structural refinements is summarized in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
. The relevant bond lengths and angles are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>
.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

Suitable single crystals of complexes 1-4 were mounted on a glass fiber, and the intensity data were collected on a Bruker APEXII area detector with graphite-monochromated MoKa radiation ( λ=0.71073Å) at 293K. Data reduction and cell refinement were performed using the SMART and SAINT programs . The absorption corrections are carried out by the empirical method. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full matrix least squares against F2 of data using SHELXTL software . All H atoms were found in different electron maps and were subsequently refined in a riding-model approximation with C-H distances ranging from 0.95 to 0.99Å . Information concerning the crystallographic data collection and structural refinements is summarized in  . The relevant bond lengths and angles are listed in  .

The synthetic routes to cuprous complexes are shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>
. The elemental analysis of complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> are in good agreement with the theoretical compositions. The four complexes are soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as DMF and DMSO; slightly soluble in ethanol, methanol and ethyl acetate; insoluble in diethyl ether and petroleum ether. elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Four new cuprous complexes were synthesized by natural volatilization, solvothermal and interfacial reaction. The synthetic routes to cuprous complexes are shown in  . The elemental analysis of complexes 1-4 are in good agreement with the theoretical compositions. The four complexes are soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as DMF and DMSO; slightly soluble in ethanol, methanol and ethyl acetate; insoluble in diethyl ether and petroleum ether. In complexes 1-4, proton signals of benzoxazole and pyridine were downfield shifted compared with free ligands, indicating that these signals are attributable to coordination species existing in solution due to an inductive effect of metal ions upon complexation.

<ce:section-title id="sect0070">X-ray structure of the four complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0075">Cuprous complex with bidentate chelating N-heterocyclic ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallized in the Triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1. It is a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-I bridged and has a centrosymmetric “dimeric” binuclear structure, where the four-membered Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> ring has a flat conformation (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
). The centrosymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of two copper(I) ions, two I anions, two 2-PBO ligands and one acetonitrile molecule. Each copper atom is four-coordinate with a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>I<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chromophore, which two N atoms come from 2-PBO and two iodine atoms. The geometry for a four-coordinate transition metal complex can be determined using the τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> geometry index, τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> = [360 - (α + β)]/141, where α and β are the largest angles around the metal's center and its value varies from 0 (in plane quadrilateral) to 1 (in regular tetrahedron) . The coordination geometry of the copper may best be described as distorted tetrahedron in which the τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> of Cu(1) is 0.872 (Cu(1) are I(1)#1-Cu(1)-I(1) = 120.53(4) Å, N(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1 = 116.46(13) Å). This geometry is adopted by the copper to relieve steric crowding. The Cu<ce:bold>∙∙∙</ce:bold>Cu distance is 2.57 Å, much smaller than Van der Waals radius (2.80 Å), this probably indicates that there is a metal-metal bond interaction.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure of the four complexes

Cuprous complex with bidentate chelating N-heterocyclic ligand

Complex 1 crystallized in the Triclinic space group P-1. It is a μ2-I bridged and has a centrosymmetric "dimeric" binuclear structure, where the four-membered Cu2I2 ring has a flat conformation ( ). The centrosymmetric unit of complex 1 consists of two copper(I) ions, two I anions, two 2-PBO ligands and one acetonitrile molecule. Each copper atom is four-coordinate with a N2I2 chromophore, which two N atoms come from 2-PBO and two iodine atoms. The geometry for a four-coordinate transition metal complex can be determined using the τ4 geometry index, τ4 =[360 - (α+β)]/141, where α and β are the largest angles around the metal's center and its value varies from 0 (in plane quadrilateral) to 1 (in regular tetrahedron) . The coordination geometry of the copper may best be described as distorted tetrahedron in which the τ4 of Cu(1) is 0.872 (Cu(1) are I(1)#1-Cu(1)-I(1) =120.53(4) Å, N(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1=116.46(13) Å). This geometry is adopted by the copper to relieve steric crowding. The Cu∙∙∙Cu distance is 2.57Å, much smaller than Van der Waals radius (2.80Å), this probably indicates that there is a metal-metal bond interaction.

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">As an important type of supermolecule interaction, π∙∙∙π superposition often involves the placement of substrate identification or complex structure. The complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> forms a supramolecular chain by π∙∙∙π, the benzoxazole rings from the adjacent units arrange in an offset face-to face fashion with the vertical distance of center to center 3.567(21) Å, suggesting significant π∙∙∙π stacking interactions, as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
. At the same time, and C-H∙∙∙I (3.122 Å) hydrogen bonds contribute to the crystal packing, helping to stabilize the crystal structure.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0080">Cuprous complexes with monodentate N-heterocyclic ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 and is a one-dimensional (1-D) infinite double-stranded stairs coordination polymer by μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I. The monodentate ligand 4-PBO coordinated to Cu(I) forming both sides of the ladder chain. Its asymmetric unit contains Cu(4-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I) unit. In <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
, each copper(I) center is four-coordinated by three I atoms and N atom of 4-PBO, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in which the τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> values of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 0.908 (α = I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1 = 117.73°, β = I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#2 = 114.13°). It is interesting that Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu interactions in the core are 2.718 and 2.884 Å, which are close to the sums of the van der Waals radii for Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu (2.80 Å) indicating weak Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu interactions which are important for the stabilization of the ladder chain. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, adjacent double-stranded stair motifs are connected together by C-H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>I (3.175 Å) interactions to generating a 2-D layer supramolecular framework (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cuprous complexes with monodentate N-heterocyclic ligand

Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 and is a one-dimensional (1-D) infinite double-stranded stairs coordination polymer by μ3-I. The monodentate ligand 4-PBO coordinated to Cu(I) forming both sides of the ladder chain. Its asymmetric unit contains Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-I) unit. In  , each copper(I) center is four-coordinated by three I atoms and N atom of 4-PBO, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in which the τ4 values of 2 is 0.908 (α=I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1=117.73°, β=I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#2=114.13°). It is interesting that Cu…Cu interactions in the core are 2.718 and 2.884Å, which are close to the sums of the van der Waals radii for Cu…Cu (2.80Å) indicating weak Cu…Cu interactions which are important for the stabilization of the ladder chain. In complex 2, adjacent double-stranded stair motifs are connected together by C-H…I (3.175Å) interactions to generating a 2-D layer supramolecular framework ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P2(1). The asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> consists of one copper(I) ion, one thiocyanate and one 4-PBO ligand. Each copper atom is a four-coordinated slightly distorted tetrahedron (τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> = 0.942), in which one nitrogen atom from thiocyanate, one nitrogen atom from 4-PBO and the other two sulfur atoms come from the two thiocyanate. Copper atoms are linked to thiocyanate ligands via μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SCN coordination to form a 2-D layer convergence network (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>
). Each nitrogen atom of the thiocyanate ligands is linear connected to only one copper atom, whereas the sulfur atom bridges two symmetry related copper atoms which are oriented in the direction of the lone-pairs of the sulfur atom. From this arrangement an interesting and novel CuSCN substructure is formed, which consists of 10-membered irregular rings with each of them built up of three copper atoms and three thiocyanate ligands (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
). The tetrahedral configuration of the copper atoms leads to the 2-D layer being corrugated. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> belongs to 6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> topology with tridentate thiocyanate as a connector (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with space group P2(1). The asymmetric unit of complex 3 consists of one copper(I) ion, one thiocyanate and one 4-PBO ligand. Each copper atom is a four-coordinated slightly distorted tetrahedron (τ4 =0.942), in which one nitrogen atom from thiocyanate, one nitrogen atom from 4-PBO and the other two sulfur atoms come from the two thiocyanate. Copper atoms are linked to thiocyanate ligands via μ3-SCN coordination to form a 2-D layer convergence network ( ). Each nitrogen atom of the thiocyanate ligands is linear connected to only one copper atom, whereas the sulfur atom bridges two symmetry related copper atoms which are oriented in the direction of the lone-pairs of the sulfur atom. From this arrangement an interesting and novel CuSCN substructure is formed, which consists of 10-membered irregular rings with each of them built up of three copper atoms and three thiocyanate ligands ( ). The tetrahedral configuration of the copper atoms leads to the 2-D layer being corrugated. Complex 3 belongs to 63 topology with tridentate thiocyanate as a connector ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0085">Cuprous complex with bridged N-heterocyclic ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c and contains rhombic Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cluster cores that are linked by two pairs of BBO bridges, forming a 1-D double chain structure in which macro rings alternately connect small rings (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>
). The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> consists of two independent copper(I) ions, two bromine anions with two azino-pyridyl ligand BBO. The copper(I) is coordinated with an N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> donor set from two N atoms provided by two different BBO and bromine anions. The complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with a τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> parameter of 0.934, in which the maximum two bond angles around copper are N(1)-Cu(1)-N(2) = 115.95° and N(2)-Cu(1)-Br(1)#1 = 112.26°. Two µ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Br ions are bound to two adjacent copper(I) ions, forming a Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rhomboid dimer. These rhomboid cores are interconnected by bridge ligand BBO to form 1-D coordination polymeric double chains structure. The 1-D coordination chains are connected by supramolecular π···π (d = 3.56 Å) interactions to form 2-D supramolecular structure (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>
).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Cuprous complex with bridged N-heterocyclic ligand

The complex 4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c and contains rhombic Cu2Br2 cluster cores that are linked by two pairs of BBO bridges, forming a 1-D double chain structure in which macro rings alternately connect small rings ( ). The asymmetric unit of 4 consists of two independent copper(I) ions, two bromine anions with two azino-pyridyl ligand BBO. The copper(I) is coordinated with an N2Br2 donor set from two N atoms provided by two different BBO and bromine anions. The complex 4 is a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry with a τ4 parameter of 0.934, in which the maximum two bond angles around copper are N(1)-Cu(1)-N(2)=115.95° and N(2)-Cu(1)-Br(1)#1=112.26°. Two µ2-Br ions are bound to two adjacent copper(I) ions, forming a Cu2Br2 rhomboid dimer. These rhomboid cores are interconnected by bridge ligand BBO to form 1-D coordination polymeric double chains structure. The 1-D coordination chains are connected by supramolecular π⋅⋅⋅π (d=3.56Å) interactions to form 2-D supramolecular structure ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0085" view="all">By comparing the ligands and complexes above-mentioned, the reason that the four copper(I) complexes showed different spatial geometric structure can be attributed to the different steric hindrance, coordination mode of the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligands and the coordination synergistic effect of halogen or pseudohalogen ions. For example, for the chelating <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligand, the halide ion participates in the coordination by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bridging, forming a binuclear copper(I) complex. Because monodentate <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligand occupies only one coordinated site, halogen or pseudohalide ions are bridged by μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> to form cuprous coordination polymers. For bidentate bridge <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligand, the halide ion participates in the coordination by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> bridging, forming Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rhombus cluster. Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>X<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rhombus cluster is connected by ligand to form one-dimensional double-stranded polymer. So we can clearly see that different types of <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic ligands lead to halogen/pseudohalide ions to participate in coordination by μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> or μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, thereby forming different structures of copper(I) complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: By comparing the ligands and complexes above-mentioned, the reason that the four copper(I) complexes showed different spatial geometric structure can be attributed to the different steric hindrance, coordination mode of the N-heterocyclic ligands and the coordination synergistic effect of halogen or pseudohalogen ions. For example, for the chelating N-heterocyclic ligand, the halide ion participates in the coordination by μ2 bridging, forming a binuclear copper(I) complex. Because monodentate N-heterocyclic ligand occupies only one coordinated site, halogen or pseudohalide ions are bridged by μ3 to form cuprous coordination polymers. For bidentate bridge N-heterocyclic ligand, the halide ion participates in the coordination by μ2 bridging, forming Cu2X2 rhombus cluster. Cu2X2 rhombus cluster is connected by ligand to form one-dimensional double-stranded polymer. So we can clearly see that different types of N-heterocyclic ligands lead to halogen/pseudohalide ions to participate in coordination by μ2 or μ3, thereby forming different structures of copper(I) complexes.

<ce:section-title id="sect0090">Powder X-ray diffraction, IR and UV–Vis spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The bulk phase purity of the complexes was examined by powder X-ray diffraction measurements. <ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
 shows the observed powder diffraction patterns acquired from the as prepared compounds together with the calculated patterns generated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Most peak positions of the simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other, confirming that a single phase (more than ~95% purity) is formed for each complex. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the microcrystalline powder samples.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray diffraction, IR and UV-Vis spectra

The bulk phase purity of the complexes was examined by powder X-ray diffraction measurements.   shows the observed powder diffraction patterns acquired from the as prepared compounds together with the calculated patterns generated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data. Most peak positions of the simulated and experimental patterns are in good agreement with each other, confirming that a single phase (more than ~95% purity) is formed for each complex. The differences in intensity may be due to the preferred orientation of the microcrystalline powder samples.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The IR spectrum exhibits the main characteristic bands of the 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO fragments for complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold>. The weaker peaks at 1257, 1271, 1220 and 1244 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> are attributed to the ν(C-O) of the oxazole rings, characteristic bands at 1541 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 1539 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 1546 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 1560 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are assigned to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C˭N) stretching vibration of the oxazole rings, respectively . For complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the absorption band 2364 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> is attributed to <ce:italic>ν(</ce:italic>C≡N). This fact agrees with the result determined by X-ray diffraction. The electronic spectra of free 2-PBO, 4-PBO, BBO and all copper(I) complexes were recorded at 298 K in DMF solution. The high energy absorption band of the four copper(I) complexes are 303, 301, 301 and 278 nm, respectively, which are assigned to ligand-centered π→π* transitions of benzene ring .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The IR spectrum exhibits the main characteristic bands of the 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO fragments for complexes 1-4. The weaker peaks at 1257, 1271, 1220 and 1244cm-1 for complexes 1-4 are attributed to the ν(C-O) of the oxazole rings, characteristic bands at 1541cm-1 for complex 1, 1539cm-1 for complex 2, 1546cm-1 for complex 3 and 1560cm-1 for complex 4 are assigned to the ν(C˭N) stretching vibration of the oxazole rings, respectively . For complex 3, the absorption band 2364cm-1 is attributed to ν(C≡N). This fact agrees with the result determined by X-ray diffraction. The electronic spectra of free 2-PBO, 4-PBO, BBO and all copper(I) complexes were recorded at 298K in DMF solution. The high energy absorption band of the four copper(I) complexes are 303, 301, 301 and 278nm, respectively, which are assigned to ligand-centered π→π* transitions of benzene ring .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0095">Photophysical properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Copper(I) complex not only have abundant photophysical properties but also their luminescence properties are obviously responsive to external environmental stimuli, which makes it potentially useful in luminescent materials . The fluorescent emission spectra of the ligands and their four complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–4 were measured in a solid state at room temperature as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>
, which depicts the color and luminescence changes for these compounds under ambient light and UV light irradiation (365 nm). Photophysical parameters for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>
. The free ligands 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO show purple fluorescent luminescence with the maximum wavelengths at 409 nm, 409 nm and 382 nm when excited at 359 nm, 360 nm and 350 nm, respectively, which may be attributed to π*-π transition . It is notable that all the complexes except <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have two emission spectral peaks. For complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> the high energy emission peak occur at 468 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 300 nm, φ = 14.4%), 446 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 295 nm, φ = 13.2%) and 466 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 294 nm, φ = 9.3%) respectively. The high energy emission lifetimes of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 0.43, 0.26 and 1.16 μs. Compared with the free 2-PBO, BBO and 4-PBO ligands, a red-shift of 59 nm was observed for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 84 nm for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 57 nm for complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge-transfer MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT . Another peak appearing at 763 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 300 nm, φ = 11.7%) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 754 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 295 nm, φ = 10.6%) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 754 nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 294 nm, φ = 7.85%) may be attributed to typical features of <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>CC emission, which arises from a mixed halogen-to-copper charge transfer and d-s,p copper centered excited state . The low energy emission lifetimes of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 0.25, 0.83 and 1.25 μs. However, when excited at λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 380 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows only one band with an emission lifetime of 1.02 μs at 605 nm (φ = 31.35%), which may be attributed to MLCT and XMCT. From the above phenomena, we can clearly find that there are two different emission peaks for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. This may be due to the presence of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-X (X = I, Br, S) in these complexes. The high emission of the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> copper(I) complexes may be attributed to the coordination of the ligand to the copper(I) ion, which enhances the rigidity of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a non-radioactive relaxation process. The <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> values of copper(I) complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> are in the order <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which is suggested that different halogens and the arylation of the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic group might has some important impacts on the luminescence properties of cuprous complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical properties

Copper(I) complex not only have abundant photophysical properties but also their luminescence properties are obviously responsive to external environmental stimuli, which makes it potentially useful in luminescent materials . The fluorescent emission spectra of the ligands and their four complexes 1-4 were measured in a solid state at room temperature as shown in  , which depicts the color and luminescence changes for these compounds under ambient light and UV light irradiation (365nm). Photophysical parameters for complexes 1-4 were listed in  . The free ligands 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO show purple fluorescent luminescence with the maximum wavelengths at 409nm, 409nm and 382nm when excited at 359nm, 360nm and 350nm, respectively, which may be attributed to π*-π transition . It is notable that all the complexes except 2 have two emission spectral peaks. For complexes 1, 3 and 4 the high energy emission peak occur at 468nm (λex = 300nm, φ=14.4%), 446nm (λex =295nm, φ=13.2%) and 466nm (λex = 294nm, φ=9.3%) respectively. The high energy emission lifetimes of complexes 1, 3 and 4 are 0.43, 0.26 and 1.16μs. Compared with the free 2-PBO, BBO and 4-PBO ligands, a red-shift of 59nm was observed for complex 1, 84nm for complex 3 and 57nm for complex 4, which may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge-transfer MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT . Another peak appearing at 763nm (λex = 300nm, φ=11.7%) for 1, 754nm (λex =295nm, φ=10.6%) for 3 and 754nm for 4 (λex =294nm, φ=7.85%) may be attributed to typical features of 3CC emission, which arises from a mixed halogen-to-copper charge transfer and d-s,p copper centered excited state . The low energy emission lifetimes of complexes 1, 3 and 4 are 0.25, 0.83 and 1.25μs. However, when excited at λex =380nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 2 shows only one band with an emission lifetime of 1.02μs at 605nm (φ=31.35%), which may be attributed to MLCT and XMCT. From the above phenomena, we can clearly find that there are two different emission peaks for complexes 1, 3 and 4. This may be due to the presence of μ2-X (X=I, Br, S) in these complexes. The high emission of the d10 copper(I) complexes may be attributed to the coordination of the ligand to the copper(I) ion, which enhances the rigidity of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a non-radioactive relaxation process. The λ max values of copper(I) complexes 1-4 are in the order 2 > 1 > 4 > 3, which is suggested that different halogens and the arylation of the N-heterocyclic group might has some important impacts on the luminescence properties of cuprous complexes.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0100">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">In this work that four new cuprous complexes with benzoxazole ligands were synthesized and characterized. The structural analysis revealed that in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, all copper(I) ions are four-coordinated and the geometric structure around the central copper(I) atom possessing slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. Through the use of different types of benzoxazole ligands and the coordination synergistic effect of halogen or pseudohalogen ions, the regulation of the structure of the cuprous complexes was achieved. Fluorescence analysis illustrated that there are two emission peaks for complexes <ce:bold>1, 3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> {high energy band: MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT; low energy band: <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>CC emission}. However, there is only one emission peaks for complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> {MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT}. The results indicate that these complexes are likely to be potential luminescent or photochemical materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work that four new cuprous complexes with benzoxazole ligands were synthesized and characterized. The structural analysis revealed that in complexes 1-4, all copper(I) ions are four-coordinated and the geometric structure around the central copper(I) atom possessing slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry. Through the use of different types of benzoxazole ligands and the coordination synergistic effect of halogen or pseudohalogen ions, the regulation of the structure of the cuprous complexes was achieved. Fluorescence analysis illustrated that there are two emission peaks for complexes 1, 3 and 4 {high energy band: MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT; low energy band: 3CC emission}. However, there is only one emission peaks for complex 2 {MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT}. The results indicate that these complexes are likely to be potential luminescent or photochemical materials.

Preparation of the cuprous complexes 1-4

Synthesis of [Cu(2-PBO)(μ2-I)]2 (1)

To a stirred solution of ligand 2-PBO (0.0196g, 0.10mmol) in hot MeOH (10mL) was added CuI (0.0190g, 0.10mmol) in CH3CN (5mL). The block crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained by evaporation the mixed solution after two weeks at room temperature. 89% yield. Anal. Calcd for C24H16Cu2I2N4O2:C, 37.28; H, 2.09; N, 7.25%. Found:C, 38.29; H, 2.27; N, 8.52%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3055 (w), 1541 (w), 1469 (m), 1429 (m), 1356 (s), 1257 (w), 1126 (m), 810 (m), 744 (s), 696 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO):δ (ppm)=7.46-7.88(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.03-8.42(m, 3H, H-Py), 8.88-8.92(m, 1H, H-Py).

Synthesis of [Cu4(4-PBO)4(μ3-I)4]n (2)

A mixture of 4-PBO (0.1mmol), CuI (0.2mmol), acetonitrile (8.0mL) wassealed in a stainless steel reactor with a 15mL Teflon liner and heated at 140°C for 3 days, and then slowly cooled to room temperature. A large amount of dark red and block-shaped crystals of were found. Yield: 92%. Calcd for C12H8CuIN2O: C, 37.28; H, 2.09; N, 7.25%. Found: C, 37.19; H, 2.02; N, 7.18%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3047 (w), 2926 (w), 1539 (w), 1473 (m), 1419 (s), 1346 (m), 1271 (m), 1111 (w), 1058 (w), 842 (m), 810 (m), 740 (s), 698 (m), 511 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO): δ (ppm)=7.51-7.92(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.12-8.34(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.77-8.96(m, 2H, H-C-N, H-Py).

Synthesis of {[Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-SCN)]2}n (3)

A solution of 2-PBO (0.0588g, 0.3mmol) in 4mL of dichloromethane was very carefully placed on the bottom of the tube. 1mL of acetonitrile as the buffer was slowly layered onto the ligand solution. A clear solution of CuSCN (0.0243g, 0.2mmol) and NH4SCN (0.0304g, 0.4mmol) in 4mL of acetonitrile was then very carefully layered on the top of the buffer solution. After 1 week, red block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and dried in vacuo. Yield: 78%. Elemental analysis for C13H8CuN3OS: C, 49.13; H, 2.54; N, 5.03%. Found: C, 49.06; H, 2.46; N, 4.95%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3109 (w), 2364 (w), 2048 (m), 1620 (s), 1546 (m), 1421 (m), 1350 (w), 1220 (w), 1060 (w), 814 (m), 752 (s), 692 (w). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO): δ (ppm)=7.48-7.88(m, 4H, H-Ar), 8.03-8.22(m, 2H, H-Py), 8.89-8.97(m, 2H, H-Py).

Synthesis of {[Cu(BBO)(μ2-Br)]2}n (4)

The synthesis of complex 4 is similar to 2 except for using BBO (0.1mmol) and CuBr (0.2mmol). Calcd for C18H16BrCuN2O2: C, 49.61; H, 3.70; N, 6.43%. Found: C, 49.52; H, 3.66; N, 6.39%. IR (KBr pellet, ν/cm-1): 3053 (w), 2943 (w), 1604 (w), 1560 (s), 1454 (m), 1244 (m), 1166 (w), 779 (w), 744 (s). 1H NMR (400MHz, d6-DMSO):δ (ppm)=2.11-2.19(m, 4H, H-CH2), 3.12-3.33(m, 4H, H-CH2), 7.45-7.92(m, 8H, -H-Ar).

<ce:section-title id="sect0080">Cuprous complexes with monodentate N-heterocyclic ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 and is a one-dimensional (1-D) infinite double-stranded stairs coordination polymer by μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I. The monodentate ligand 4-PBO coordinated to Cu(I) forming both sides of the ladder chain. Its asymmetric unit contains Cu(4-PBO)(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-I) unit. In <ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
, each copper(I) center is four-coordinated by three I atoms and N atom of 4-PBO, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in which the τ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> values of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 0.908 (α = I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1 = 117.73°, β = I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#2 = 114.13°). It is interesting that Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu interactions in the core are 2.718 and 2.884 Å, which are close to the sums of the van der Waals radii for Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu (2.80 Å) indicating weak Cu<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>Cu interactions which are important for the stabilization of the ladder chain. In complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, adjacent double-stranded stair motifs are connected together by C-H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>I (3.175 Å) interactions to generating a 2-D layer supramolecular framework (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
).</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sect0095">Photophysical properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Copper(I) complex not only have abundant photophysical properties but also their luminescence properties are obviously responsive to external environmental stimuli, which makes it potentially useful in luminescent materials . The fluorescent emission spectra of the ligands and their four complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–4 were measured in a solid state at room temperature as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>
, which depicts the color and luminescence changes for these compounds under ambient light and UV light irradiation (365 nm). Photophysical parameters for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>
. The free ligands 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO show purple fluorescent luminescence with the maximum wavelengths at 409 nm, 409 nm and 382 nm when excited at 359 nm, 360 nm and 350 nm, respectively, which may be attributed to π*-π transition . It is notable that all the complexes except <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have two emission spectral peaks. For complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> the high energy emission peak occur at 468 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 300 nm, φ = 14.4%), 446 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 295 nm, φ = 13.2%) and 466 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 294 nm, φ = 9.3%) respectively. The high energy emission lifetimes of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 0.43, 0.26 and 1.16 μs. Compared with the free 2-PBO, BBO and 4-PBO ligands, a red-shift of 59 nm was observed for complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 84 nm for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 57 nm for complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, which may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge-transfer MLCT[d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup>(Cu)→π*] and XMCT . Another peak appearing at 763 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 300 nm, φ = 11.7%) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 754 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 295 nm, φ = 10.6%) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 754 nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 294 nm, φ = 7.85%) may be attributed to typical features of <ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>CC emission, which arises from a mixed halogen-to-copper charge transfer and d-s,p copper centered excited state . The low energy emission lifetimes of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 0.25, 0.83 and 1.25 μs. However, when excited at λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 380 nm, the fluorescence spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows only one band with an emission lifetime of 1.02 μs at 605 nm (φ = 31.35%), which may be attributed to MLCT and XMCT. From the above phenomena, we can clearly find that there are two different emission peaks for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. This may be due to the presence of μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-X (X = I, Br, S) in these complexes. The high emission of the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> copper(I) complexes may be attributed to the coordination of the ligand to the copper(I) ion, which enhances the rigidity of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a non-radioactive relaxation process. The <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">max</ce:inf> values of copper(I) complexes <ce:bold>1–4</ce:bold> are in the order <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which is suggested that different halogens and the arylation of the <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-heterocyclic group might has some important impacts on the luminescence properties of cuprous complexes.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Cuprous complexes with monodentate N-heterocyclic ligand

Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1 and is a one-dimensional (1-D) infinite double-stranded stairs coordination polymer by μ3-I. The monodentate ligand 4-PBO coordinated to Cu(I) forming both sides of the ladder chain. Its asymmetric unit contains Cu(4-PBO)(μ3-I) unit. In  , each copper(I) center is four-coordinated by three I atoms and N atom of 4-PBO, forming a slightly distorted tetrahedral geometry in which the τ4 values of 2 is 0.908 (α=I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#1=117.73°, β=I(1)-Cu(1)-I(1)#2=114.13°). It is interesting that Cu…Cu interactions in the core are 2.718 and 2.884Å, which are close to the sums of the van der Waals radii for Cu…Cu (2.80Å) indicating weak Cu…Cu interactions which are important for the stabilization of the ladder chain. In complex 2, adjacent double-stranded stair motifs are connected together by C-H…I (3.175Å) interactions to generating a 2-D layer supramolecular framework ( ).

Photophysical properties

Copper(I) complex not only have abundant photophysical properties but also their luminescence properties are obviously responsive to external environmental stimuli, which makes it potentially useful in luminescent materials . The fluorescent emission spectra of the ligands and their four complexes 1-4 were measured in a solid state at room temperature as shown in  , which depicts the color and luminescence changes for these compounds under ambient light and UV light irradiation (365nm). Photophysical parameters for complexes 1-4 were listed in  . The free ligands 2-PBO, 4-PBO and BBO show purple fluorescent luminescence with the maximum wavelengths at 409nm, 409nm and 382nm when excited at 359nm, 360nm and 350nm, respectively, which may be attributed to π*-π transition . It is notable that all the complexes except 2 have two emission spectral peaks. For complexes 1, 3 and 4 the high energy emission peak occur at 468nm (λex = 300nm, φ=14.4%), 446nm (λex =295nm, φ=13.2%) and 466nm (λex = 294nm, φ=9.3%) respectively. The high energy emission lifetimes of complexes 1, 3 and 4 are 0.43, 0.26 and 1.16μs. Compared with the free 2-PBO, BBO and 4-PBO ligands, a red-shift of 59nm was observed for complex 1, 84nm for complex 3 and 57nm for complex 4, which may be attributed to metal-to-ligand charge-transfer MLCT[d10(Cu)→π*] and XMCT . Another peak appearing at 763nm (λex = 300nm, φ=11.7%) for 1, 754nm (λex =295nm, φ=10.6%) for 3 and 754nm for 4 (λex =294nm, φ=7.85%) may be attributed to typical features of 3CC emission, which arises from a mixed halogen-to-copper charge transfer and d-s,p copper centered excited state . The low energy emission lifetimes of complexes 1, 3 and 4 are 0.25, 0.83 and 1.25μs. However, when excited at λex =380nm, the fluorescence spectrum of 2 shows only one band with an emission lifetime of 1.02μs at 605nm (φ=31.35%), which may be attributed to MLCT and XMCT. From the above phenomena, we can clearly find that there are two different emission peaks for complexes 1, 3 and 4. This may be due to the presence of μ2-X (X=I, Br, S) in these complexes. The high emission of the d10 copper(I) complexes may be attributed to the coordination of the ligand to the copper(I) ion, which enhances the rigidity of the ligand and thus reduces the loss of energy through a non-radioactive relaxation process. The λ max values of copper(I) complexes 1-4 are in the order 2 > 1 > 4 > 3, which is suggested that different halogens and the arylation of the N-heterocyclic group might has some important impacts on the luminescence properties of cuprous complexes.

metadata.title: Synthesis and photoluminescence properties of different structural cuprous complexes regulated by benzoxazole ligands and halogen/pseudohalide ions
